content.user_title: Create Autonomous Agents for Claude Code Plugins
content.value_statement: Building effective autonomous agents requires understanding agent structure, triggering conditions, and system prompt design. This skill provides comprehensive guidance and templates for creating production-ready agents that handle complex multi-step tasks independently.
actual_capabilities: Create agent markdown files with YAML frontmatter including name, description, model, and color
Write effective system prompts with responsibilities, process steps, and output formats
Design triggering conditions using description field with concrete example blocks
Validate agent files using provided bash script for structure and content verification
Apply AI-assisted generation to create agents from natural language descriptions
limitations: Agents run as subprocesses within Claude Code, cannot operate independently
Tool access is restricted to those specified in the agent configuration
Agent behavior is governed by system prompt and cannot modify itself at runtime
Agents require proper triggering conditions to activate, cannot self-initiate in all scenarios

prompt_templates.title: Basic Agent Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent that helps with [specific task]. Use inherit model and blue color.

prompt_templates.title: Review Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a code-reviewer agent that analyzes changes for quality issues, security vulnerabilities, and best practices. Include 2 triggering examples.

prompt_templates.title: Generation Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a test-generator agent following the production templates. It should trigger after code is written without tests.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent with custom system prompt: role as [expert persona], core responsibilities [list], process steps [detailed workflow], output format [structured format], edge cases [handling guidance].

output_examples.input: Create an agent that reviews pull requests
output: Triggering: When user asks to review PRs, check code changes, or analyze pull requests
System prompt includes: Core responsibilities, review process steps, quality standards, output format, edge cases

best_practices: Write specific triggering conditions with 2-4 concrete example blocks showing when and why the agent should activate
Use second person voice in system prompts (You are..., You will...) with clear responsibilities and step-by-step processes
Restrict agent tool access to minimum required (principle of least privilege) using the tools field
anti_patterns: Using generic descriptions without concrete examples, making agent triggering unreliable
Writing vague system prompts without clear responsibilities, process steps, or output format
Granting all tools to agents when only specific tools are needed, violating least privilege

faq.question: What models can agents use?
faq.answer: Agents can use inherit (parent model), sonnet (balanced), opus (capable), or haiku (fast). Use inherit unless specific model capabilities are needed.

faq.question: What is the maximum system prompt length?
faq.answer: System prompts should stay under 10,000 characters. Recommended length is 500-3,000 characters for most agents.

faq.question: How do agents integrate with plugins?
faq.answer: Agents live in the agents/ directory as markdown files. Claude Code auto-disccovers all .md files in this directory.

faq.question: Is agent data safe?
faq.answer: Agents only access tools specified in their configuration. Read-only agents can be restricted to Read, Grep, and Glob tools.

faq.question: Why is my agent not triggering?
faq.answer: Check that description includes Use this agent when... pattern, contains <example> blocks, and user messages match example phrasing.

faq.question: How does this differ from commands?
faq.answer: Agents handle autonomous multi-step tasks, while commands are for user-initiated single actions. Agents maintain context across complex workflows.
